The game received a cartridge release in 2017 courtesy of PlayOnRetro with a PVC box and reversible cover, translucent violet cartridge, full colour manual and a postcard.

sample_screenshots.caption: Introduction screen for the first planelago
The coloured area that marks the exit, but only if you have found all keys.

title: Miniplanets

description:
Miniplanets (Deluxe Edition) is a Special Edition of the basic cartridge release of Miniplanets. It includes:* Miniplanets

  • 3D keyring
  • Cardboard box
  • Full color manual
  • Postcard
  • PVC box with reversible cover
  • Translucent violet cartridge

The keyring and cardboard box are the two items exclusive to this edition, which cost € 10 more.
title: Miniplanets (Deluxe Edition)

description:
Bomb on Basic City is a homebrew Genesis game inspired by Bomb on Pixel City titles. In ten zones the player controls a plane using a 2D side view and needs to bomb the buildings below. The background scrolls and wraps around, but the same applies to the plane when it reaches the right side of the screen and at a faster speed. With each pass the plane can only drop one bomb so it needs to be timed carefully to target a specific building or one of the enemies below firing at the plane. With every pass the plane also flies four pixels lower, providing less room to time the bomb and avoid enemy fire.

The speed of the plane can be influenced by accelerating or braking, but it cannot be stopped entirely. Hits are rewarded with points, but also with bonuses that float upwards. They include a move bonus that allows the plane to fly up and down, the ability to launch three bombs at once and a buckler bonus that protects the plane against AA fire. A POW bonus is provided for every score and combo. When the POW meter is full a super bomb can be dropped.

The game fits the developer Papi series of games so here the character controlling the game is Papi Commando. The Bomb on Pixel City games it draws its inspiration from reference the pixels of systems such as the Atari 2600. In this game this is changed as a humorous take on programming languages as Papi Commando needs to prevent Basic City (named after the Basic language) against the C++ invading force.
title: Bomb on Basic City

description:
Bomb on Basic City: Special Edition is a physical special edition release of the updated 2018 version of the homebrew Genesis game Bomb on Basic City originally released in 2016. This entry covers the physical cartridge release of the game as there was also a ROM download release called Bomb on Basic City (Special Edition) where the differences between the 2016 and the 2018 version of the game are described in full.

This release contains:

  • Bomb on Basic City (2018 version on a cartridge)
  • Papy Commando Tennis (demo version, on the same cartridge)
  • Cardboard sleeve for the packaging
  • PVC case with a colour cover
  • Full colour manual in English and French (40 pages)
  • Full colour making-of square fold in English and French (44 pages)
  • 10 bonus cards with cheat codes
title: Bomb on Basic City: Special Edition

description:
Bomb on Basic City: Special Edition is an updated release of the 2016 homebrew Genesis game Bomb on Basic City. This entry covers the download version of the game as there was also a physical cartridge release called Bomb on Basic City: Special Edition.

This updated release has updated graphics, new bonus zones, new characters, a new zone selection screen, new music tracks, optimized code, a new Time Attack mode with support to compare the fastest times on the developer's website, and a demo of Papi Commando Tennis.
title: Bomb on Basic City: Special Edition

description:
La Citadelle du Chaos is a homebrew Genesis game and an unlicensed adaptation in French of the Steve Jackson adventure gamebook The Citadel of Chaos first published in 1983. As a typical Choose-Your-Own-Adventure game most of the game consists of text with a few illustrations. At crucial points various options are presented to proceed, leading to different outcomes. The story tells about an adventurer magician who is on a quest to locate and confront the wizard Balthus Dire. To reach him a citadel needs to be navigated. He needs to avoid monsters and collect artefacts to gain access to the inner sanctum.

At the start of the game a hero is created based on dice rolls determining ability, endurance, chance and magic points. Magic points can be divided over twelve categories such as fire, force, levitation, luck, protection, telepathy etc. Game options include automatic or custom hero creation, toggling the scenario text, text speed and font selection.

sample_screenshots.caption: A page with a large illustration

title: La Citadelle du Chaos

description: Angry Birds in Russia is unlicensed Genesis game and an unofficial Angry Birds game as well. The basic gameplay is identical to the Angry Birds games. By using the catapult, loaded with one of several different species of birds, the player must throw birds to the pigs. To complete a level, all pigs must be smashed.
title: Angry Birds in Russia

description:
Tänzer is a homebrew action title inspired by games like Strider, OSman and Hagane: The Final Conflict, the art of Keita Amemiya and Roger Dean, and anime series like Guyver. The protagonist is a ballet dancer who is unexpectedly hit by a bright purple light at night in an apartment, just a week before the premiere of the ballet version of The Ariane. After the character wakes up the body is transformed and the world is in chaos. Each level has a different setting, ranging from the Old West to Ancient Rome. Levels are made up of several stages with mini bosses and then a large boss at the end of the level, acting as the guardian of that era.

In this 2D side-scrolling platformer the character can freely run left or right, jump and crouch. The jumping height is affected by how long the button is held down and jumping again provides a double and then a triple jump. Expert jumping can lead to an infinite amount of jumps because when an enemy is attacked while in the air, the counter is decreased so an additional jump can be performed. Enemies are engaged using six way fire with horizontal, vertical and diagonal slashes, and the attack button can be held for auto fire. Levels contain treasure chests with more gold, extra energy and other items. By destroying parts of the scenery secret pick-up items and stages can be discovered.

Defeated enemies leave behind gold that can be forged into a transmutation ability, allowing for special attacks. The top right side of the screen shows the selected ability and how much the meter needed to perform it contains. In the pause menu a different ability can be selected. Forging abilities is done at the home base between levels, a space and time ship used to travel between time periods. Energy can also be replenished there through body repair. There are four abilities and they can be upgraded to make them more effective. At the home base it is also possible to forge a projectile weapon and the ability to save (but only while the game is active, the save disappears when the console is turned off).
title: Tänzer

description:
Mega Marble World is a homebrew Genesis game. It is a puzzle game that consists of 50 rooms where a ball needs to be guided to the exit. Using the four direction keys the ball can be moved in any direction and will automatically follow that path until an obstacle is encountered so the ball cannot be stopped halfway the trajectory. There are no enemies, but a lot of thinking is required to get the ball to reach the exit. There are bottomless pits and traps to take into account as well.

Rather that separate levels, the entire game is shaped like a large dungeon maze where all room are connected on a large world map that can also be consulted. Often rooms have multiple exits and the easiest one is not always the best option to progress. Players also discover multiple paths, portal and secret corridors. The game keeps track of the elapsed time and the number of moves needed. Using a password system it is possible to continue at the last room. Some rooms are very small, but there are also huge ones where the camera zooms out at the start. The goal is to reach the exit of the dungeon in a fast time.
title: Mega Marble World

description: Hangman SG is a homebrew version of the popular Hangman game. Designed as a single-player game the player needs to guess a word, letter by letter, in a limited amount of turns. There is a normal and a hard difficulty mode based on the word choice and a large dictionary is used. The game uses a limited amount of colours, a crudely drawn stickman and there is a cheery music track. The game was released on a cartridge with a limited print run of 100 copies and the title screen was personalized with the buyer's name.
title: Hangman SG

description:
Fix-It Felix Jr. is a homebrew game that presents itself as a port of the fictional 1984 game of the same title by the fictional TobiKomi Corporation from the 2012 animated Disney movie Wreck-it Ralph. The gameplay draws inspiration from titles like Donkey Kong and Wrecking Crew.

At the start of the game a mad Ralph is awoken when his stump is moved for the construction of a large apartment building called Niceland. Ralph goes to the building and smashes its windows. It is now up to Felix it to fix that. The building consists of several levels that are presented as fixed, single screen. At the start of the level Felix has 45 seconds to fix all windows on three floors. He can move freely and jumps up or moves down. Meanwhile Ralph moves around on the top level and drops bricks that hurt Felix, who starts with three lives. Every hit removes one.

Points are scored by fixing the windows with bonus points for the remaining time. When done the game moves to a new screen at a higher level. Gradually new elements are introduced such as birds that fly in a horizontal line and appear from the side of the screen. The game keeps track of the high score and the game can also be played in a Marathon mode. The game is completed when five levels all cleared. Felix then receives a medal at the top of the building and the game is restarted with a higher speed, with the score kept.

The game was released on a cartridge in two small print runs. In the second run some bugs were fixed. It is not identical to the game of the same name released in the same year by Future Driver.
title: Fix-It Felix Jr.

description:
Fix-It Felix Jr. is a homebrew game that presents itself as a port of the fictional 1984 game of the same title by the fictional TobiKomi Corporation from the 2012 animated Disney movie Wreck-it Ralph. The gameplay draws inspiration from titles like Donkey Kong and Wrecking Crew.

Ralph is on the Niceland apartment building where he has smashed its windows. It is now up to Felix it to fix that. The building consists of several floors with vertical, 2D scrolling as Felix moves up. Felix needs to fix all the windows without time pressure. He can move freely and jumps up or moves down. Meanwhile Ralph moves around on the top level and drops bricks that hurt Felix, who starts with three lives. Every hit removes one. When Felix gets too close, Ralph moves higher until the top of the building is reached.

200 points are scored for each fixed window and the game keeps track of the high scores. There are also birds that fly in a horizontal line and appear from the side of the screen. Felix receives a medal at the top of the building and then the residents throw off Ralph, which ends the game.

It is not identical to the game of the same name released in the same year by Airwalk Studios.

sample_screenshots.caption: The residents throw off Ralph and this ends the game.

title: Fix-It Felix Jr.

description:
Racer is a homebrew puzzle game inspired by one of the puzzles in the 1997 PC title Safecracker. One of the rooms in the mansion has an arcade machine where a puzzle needs to be solved after inserting a key card. The concept is based on a single screen with a street plan, a starting position for a car, a finish point and a trajectory between them. To solve the puzzle the player needs to use the handles at the bottom to steer the car left and right based on the displayed trajectory. The car does not move however so the entire sequence of turns needs to be completed just by following the path by mentally visualizing it.

Initially created as an experiment with the 16-bit adventure/visual novel engine GINCS in 2007 the game was eventually finished in 2013 with eight levels based on the concept. Only two actions are used to move left and right. The game confirms if a turn is correct after each input. As soon as a mistake is made, the car crashes and the level needs to be restarted. A next level becomes a bit more difficult based on the number of turns. Some music is included as well. Between levels screenshots are shown from Genesis racing games.

After the download release in 2013 the game received a cartridge run of 25 copies in 2004 and there was a second edition in 2019.

sample_screenshots.caption: At the start of the first level the game zooms in on the cabinet, identical to the one in Safecracker because it was based on a screenshot.
A screen from another Genesis racing game after completing the second level.
The trajectory for the first level
These are the only actions you will perform.
A scene from the help screen

title: Racer

description: Sacred Line: Genesis is a homebrew visual novel about the private detective Ellen who operates in Eastern Europe. She inherited the business from her missing sister Sarah, but when she is about to close it she receives an anonymous call tasking her to locate a hidden forest outpost. The entire story is told through still images with 3D graphics. There are horror elements to the game and most of the interaction is based on a number of choices using a menu structure. These choices can lead to many different endings such as a normal one, a secret one and several that end with death. There is also a text-based dice fighting system and the developer encourages to play it with a real dice. When dead the game restarts from the last checkpoint. It includes an in-game encyclopedia to learn more about the characters. There is a PCM based soundtrack that sounds like the output of a Game Boy Advance title.
title: Sacred Line: Genesis

description:
Joey, a kangaroo, lives with his family in northern Australia. Their peaceful life is interrupted by the invasion of a group of poachers who take away several of his family members, so Joey sets out on a journey to bring them back.

Outback Joey is the only game released for the HeartBeat Personal Trainer, a Sega Genesis-based fitness system. Using a pulse sensor and game control pads mounted to an exercise bike, stairclimer, treadmill or ski machine, players have to exercise while playing an otherwise traditional 2D platformer. The player's heartbeat is directly tied to the player character's in-game speed, with a healthy heartbeat allowing him to move faster and a resting heartbeat slowing him down to a slog. Players can create a profile with their name, age, and gender, and their health data is tracked persistently over time to let them track their progress.

sample_screenshots.caption: Your reward for finishing a stage is a warm handshake

title: Outback Joey

description: Runes is a falling block puzzle game inspired by the classic game Columns. The game has been programmed for the Sega Genesis/Mega Drive and is intended to be played with an emulator. The player has to drop runes in such a way that lines of three matching runes are formed either on the up-down, left-right, or diagonal axis. Stacking runes until they reach the board's top border ends the game.
title: Runes

description: Fatal Smarties is a 2D side-scrolling action game for two players that need to work together. It was created as a homebrew Genesis / SEGA Mega Drive title in 48 hours for the Global Game Jam. The two players control two hillbilly heroes that move around on a single homemade flippercopter. They need to repel demonic waves of evil as the occultic ritual-performing locals have taken things out of control. One player flies the flippercopter and the other player shoots. It has an endless number of waves. The characters can be hit twice before the game is over. After being hit once, there is a period of five seconds where they remain vulnerable for a second shot. If they survive that period, everything returns to normal.

sample_screenshots.caption: A large enemy that returns several times, but with different shooting patterns.
An updated SEGA logo adapted for the Global Game Jam 16.
Killed by the enemies near the bottom of the screen.

title: Fatal Smarties

description:
The SEGA Genesis version of Sangokushi V is an unlicensed port of the Sangokushi V. The game remains identical to its counterpart on other computer and console platforms. It is the fifth game in the popular turn-based strategy game series, based on the classic medieval Chinese novel "San Guo" ("Three Kingdoms"). Its events occur in the third century AD, during the Later Han Dynasty. Several army leaders (the most important ones being Liu Bei, Cao Cao, Sun Jian) are trying to unite China under their rule, and each one strives to defeat his opponents.

The game offers many innovations. The player doesn't only participate in wars, but also manages their country, and learns resource management of people and goods. A "Reputation" parameter directly affects the people's opinion of the player as their leader. Multiplayer allows participation of up to eight players (playing the eight main characters).
title: Sangokushi V

description: Wacky Races is a previously-unreleased racing game created for the SEGA Genesis in 1993, based on the Hanna Barbera cartoon. While completed by the developers, it was ultimately canned because the company didn't have the license to the show. The game's file occasionally appeared online starting in 2020, but it was released on itch.io in 2023 by developer Julian Scott.
title: Wacky Races

description:
Fight for Vengeance is a 1-on-1 fighting game, similar to Street Fighter II. In the year 2033 corrupt megacorporations through unscrupulous reasearch accidentally open up another dimension.

The game offers six playable characters plus a secret boss character. Each character has a few special moves that function similarly to Street Fighter II.
title: Fight for Vengeance

description:
The Valis Collection triple-cartridge boxset contains the 2023 re-issues of:

  • Valis
  • Syd of Valis
  • Valis III

The games themselves are the same editions that were released individually. It also includes a decorative acrylic stand with characters from the games.
title: Valis Collection

description:
The evil Biscuit Head is one again threatening Biscuit Land, and the super hero Rocket Panda blasts off to save his home and rescue his friends.

Jetpack around the maze to find the key and the exit door to go to the next level. 3 of Rocket Panda's captured badger friends can also be found in each level. Normally Rocket Panda dies from one hit, but once rescued badgers will follow Panda around and serve as shields — if hit by an enemy a badger will be lost instead.
For additional points each level has a number of biscuits to collect, as well as a second batch of hidden "special" biscuits. At least one badger must be rescued to get any score.
Tea cups charge up a boost move that Rocket Panda can use to smash through certain obstacles.

The game features over 60 levels spread over 7 worlds, and each world ends with a boss battle.
An Asteroids-like top-down shooter minigame is also included.
title: Rocket Panda

description:
The Toaplan Shooters four-cartridge boxset contains the 2021 re-issues of:

  • Fire Shark
  • Hellfire
  • Truxton
  • Zero Wing

The games themselves are the same editions that were released individually. Also included is a Zero Wing pin and a thank-you card from Toaplan founder Masahiro Yuge.
title: Toaplan Shooters (Collector's Edition)
